info.game_comments:
First game of Season 34.
New title graphics.

(1, 1).clue: "Have fun in" this country! "But remember the State Department travel warning of Taliban insurgents in Kabul!"

(3, 1).clue: Don't procrastinate,get your copy of Eckhart Tolle's spiritual self-help book "The Power of" this

(4, 1).clue: A slump in comic book sales drove it into bankruptcy in 1996; since then its cinematic universe alone has raked in $10 billion

(5, 1).clue: Route 495 takes those in New Jersey to Hell's Kitchen via this "presidential" tunnel

(6, 1).clue: It means "severe", as in "we have to resort to" these "measures"

(1, 2).clue: "It's OK, applicant! You didn't want to go to" this Calif. university a 6-mile drive from the Googleplex "anyway"

(3, 2).clue: In dealing with others, we need to set these lines, the title of a book subtitled "When to Say Yes, How to Say No"

(4, 2).clue: On the verge of going bust in 1997, it was saved by a $150 million investment by rival Microsoft

(5, 2).clue: This state's Highway 67 will get you a nice view of Devils Head Mountain in Pike National Forest

(6, 2).clue: Term for someone who can't remember who he is

(1, 3).clue: "Tummyache? Next time, take a close look at" this "C" food "casino", made with wine, Parmesan &  bacon

(3, 3).clue: "Quantum Healing" & other books by this New Delhi-born man aim to put you on the path to wellness

(4, 3).clue: It went from filing for bankruptcy in 2011 to merging with U.S. Airways & becoming the world's largest airline in 2014

(5, 3).clue: West of Akron, Route 57 takes you over this 4-letter river, & you don't have to pay a toll to Charon

(6, 3).clue: Late in 2016 President Obama expelled from the U.S. several Russian members of this corps

(1, 4).clue: "Nice surgery! You finally vented" this soft, purplish organ, that filters blood & stores platelets

(3, 4).clue: One purpose of this evangelical leader's "The Purpose Driven Life" is to answer the question "What am I here for?"

(4, 4).clue: It took more than a "moment", but this Rochester, N.Y. company emerged from bankruptcy & still sells cameras

(5, 4).clue: Take the 395 in this state to Inyo National Forest and to Devils Postpile along the middle fork of the San Joaquin River

(6, 4).clue: Meaning "antiquated", it has nothing to do with a Biblical boat

(1, 5).clue: "Sorry you two had" these 14-letter "differences" that couples often cite as legal grounds for divorce

(3, 5).clue: This self-help guru penned bestsellers like "Your Erroneous Zones" and "The Power of Intention"

(4, 5).clue: U.S. taxpayers ponied up $180 billion to rescue this 3-letter insurance co., but got it all back, plus a profit

(5, 5).clue: Highway 71 gets you to America's deepest gorge, Hells Canyon, & this river that flows through it

(6, 5).clue: St. Nilus of Ancyra was AKA Nilus the this type of monk who lives simply

(1, 1).clue: The flamboyant type of this medieval style of architecture features curves in the tracery that resemble flames

(2, 1).clue: She headed to Netflix for "The Leather Special"

(3, 1).clue: This type of body of water is in a nickname for Massachusetts

(4, 1).clue: This man announced his periodic law of the elements before the Russian Chemical Society in 1869

(6, 1).clue: In 1453 the Turks captured Constantinople & killed the 11th emperor there to have this very appropriate name

(1, 2).clue: This uppermost part of the capital of a column shares its name with an ancient calculator

(2, 2).clue: This gravel-voiced funny guy won a Grammy for his comedy album "Stark Raving Black"

(3, 2).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew shows a diagram of troop movements on the monitor.) At the first Battle of Bull Run, Union troops threatened a decisive breakthrough but couldn't get past a Virginia brigade, earning its commander this nickname

(4, 2).clue: In 1880 Alphonse Laveran discovered that parasites caused this disease named for the "bad air" thought to cause it

(5, 2).clue: Cesar Chavez heard Latino leaders say "No se puede" & immediately his United Farm Workers had this slogan

(6, 2).clue: In spring 1939 the U.K. instituted this compulsory measure in peacetime for the first time

(1, 3).clue: As seen here, vermiculated masonry features wandering grooves that resemble tracks of these creatures

(2, 3).clue: He's the late, great comedy legend seen here

(3, 3).clue: A gaudy, glittering metallic substance is in this nickname for the L.A. movie industry

(4, 3).clue: There would be no sodas without the invention of carbonated water by this scientist as part of his 18th c. oxygen studies

(5, 3).clue: Order camarones in a restaurant & you'll get this seafood

(6, 3).clue: A symbol of this intellectual movement, Frederick II was dubbed "philosopher king"

(1, 4).clue: Flat roofs & lots of glass were a trend around 1950, thus the alliterative term this period "modern"

(2, 4).clue: He asked, "Do you think that God gets stoned once in a while? Look at a platypus. I think so"

(3, 4).clue: Robert A. Lewis was the co-pilot of the plane with this nickname that dropped the A-bomb on Hiroshima

(4, 4).clue: Around 1929 this physicist with labs later named for him built the first cyclotron to produce artificial radioactivity

(5, 4).clue: It means "market" & precedes bursatil to mean "stock market"

(6, 4).clue: In 1622 this cardinal was elected president of the Sorbonne & began rebuilding the university; he's buried in its chapel

(1, 5).clue: In 1923 this Swiss mister with a French nom de architecture wrote, "A house is a machine for living in"

(2, 5).clue: George Carlin said, "Scientists have discovered a vaccine for" this, but "no one is showing the slightest interest"

(3, 5).clue: Alexander Pope's nicknames include "The Bard of Twickenham" & "The Sweet" this bird "of Thames"

(4, 5).clue: In 1807 President Jefferson created the Coast Survey; today, it's part of this oceanic agency
(4, 5).correct response: NOAA, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration

(5, 5).clue: "¿Cómo estás?" is casual; "¿cómo está" this pronoun, more formal

(6, 5).clue: King Zog I ruled this Balkan country until 1939; Communist Enver Hoxha would lead it from 1944 to 1985

(0, 0).clue: In 1929 Georgia O'Keeffe painted the tree in New Mexico under which this British-born author used to write
